Title: Prove that $ \det \left( A^{-1} \right) = \frac{1}{\det(A)} $
Content: If I have a non-singular matrix $\bf A$ , how can I prove the following? $$ \det \left( {\bf A}^{-1} \right) = \frac{1}{\det({\bf A})} $$ I know that ${\bf A} {\bf A}^{-1} = {\bf I}$ , but I am not sure what to do with that knowledge.
AcceptedAnswer: first of all we know that $$\det(A \cdot  B)=\det(A)\times\det(B)$$ also we know that $$A\times A^{-1}=I$$ we know that $$\det(A \cdot A^{-1})=\det(I)$$ or $$\det(A)\times\det(A^{-1})=\det(I)$$ Can you continue from this? Ask yourself: what is $\det(I)$?) Take the example of the $3\times 3$ identity matrix: $$ I =  \begin{pmatrix}1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$$ $$ \det(I) = 1$$ So, $$\det(A)\times\det(A^{-1})=1$$ or $$\boxed{\det(A^{-1})=\frac{1}{\det(A)}}$$
